message:
If you *never* want to have a null return value, then you'll have to handle retries and whatnot inside your factory method.

If you want a single null return value but then have that mean "recompute this next time", then there isn't a way to support that - yet. I'm working on it: [https://github.com/StephenCleary/AsyncEx/issues/91](https://github.com/StephenCleary/AsyncEx/issues/91)

In the meantime, you could throw an exception from your factory method instead of returning null (and have your consuming code catch the exception and treat that as a null), and use AsyncLazyFlags.RetryOnFailure.
